@graph.d3f:definition: Agent authentication is the process of verifying the identities of agents to ensure they are authorized and trustworthy participants within a system.
@graph.rdfs:label: Agent Authentication

@graph.d3f:definition: Modifying an application's configuration to reduce its attack surface.
@graph.rdfs:label: Application Configuration Hardening

@graph.d3f:definition: Application Hardening makes an executable application more resilient to a class of exploits which either introduce new code or execute unwanted existing code. These techniques may be applied at compile-time or on an application binary.
@graph.rdfs:label: Application Hardening

@graph.d3f:definition: Using biological measures in order to authenticate a user.
@graph.rdfs:label: Biometric Authentication

@graph.d3f:definition: Cryptographically authenticating the bootloader software before system boot.
@graph.rdfs:label: Bootloader Authentication

@graph.d3f:definition: Requiring a digital certificate in order to authenticate a user.
@graph.rdfs:label: Certificate-based Authentication

@graph.d3f:definition: Persisting either a server's X.509 certificate or their public key and comparing that to server's presented identity to allow for greater client confidence in the remote server's identity for SSL connections.
@graph.rdfs:label: Certificate Pinning

@graph.d3f:definition: Certificate rotation involves replacing digital certificates and their private keys to maintain cryptographic integrity and trust, mitigating key compromise risks and ensuring continuous secure communications.
@graph.rdfs:label: Certificate Rotation

@graph.d3f:definition: Credential Hardening techniques modify system or network properties in order to protect system or network/domain credentials.
@graph.rdfs:label: Credential Hardening

@graph.d3f:definition: Credential rotation is a security procedure in which authentication credentials, such as passwords, API keys, or certificates, are regularly changed or replaced to minimize the risk of unauthorized access.
@graph.rdfs:label: Credential Rotation

@graph.d3f:definition: The systematic removal of hard-coded credentials from source code to prevent accidental exposure and unauthorized access.
@graph.rdfs:label: Credential Scrubbing

@graph.d3f:definition: Removing unreachable or "dead code" from compiled source code.
@graph.rdfs:label: Dead Code Elimination

@graph.d3f:definition: Encrypting a hard disk partition to prevent cleartext access to a file system.
@graph.rdfs:label: Disk Encryption

@graph.d3f:definition: Ensuring the integrity of drivers loaded during initialization of the operating system.
@graph.rdfs:label: Driver Load Integrity Checking

@graph.d3f:definition: Validates that a referenced exception handler pointer is a valid exception handler.
@graph.rdfs:label: Exception Handler Pointer Validation

@graph.d3f:definition: Encrypting a file using a cryptographic key.
@graph.rdfs:label: File Encryption

@graph.d3f:definition: Ensuring that an integer is within a valid range.
@graph.rdfs:label: Integer Range Validation

@graph.d3f:definition: Ensuring that a pointer accurately references the beginning of a designated memory block.
@graph.rdfs:label: Memory Block Start Validation

@graph.d3f:definition: Authenticating the sender of a message and ensuring message integrity.
@graph.rdfs:label: Message Authentication

@graph.d3f:definition: Encrypting a message body using a cryptographic key.
@graph.rdfs:label: Message Encryption

@graph.d3f:definition: Email or Messaging Hardening includes measures taken to ensure the confidentiality and integrity of user to user computer messages.
@graph.rdfs:label: Message Hardening

@graph.d3f:definition: Requiring proof of two or more pieces of evidence in order to authenticate a user.
@graph.rdfs:label: Multi-factor Authentication

@graph.d3f:definition: Checking if a pointer is NULL.
@graph.rdfs:label: Null Pointer Checking

@graph.d3f:definition: A one-time password is valid for only one user authentication.
@graph.rdfs:label: One-time Password

@graph.d3f:definition: Password authentication is a security mechanism used to verify the identity of a user or entity attempting to access a system or resource by requiring the input of a secret string of characters, known as a password, that is associated with the user or entity.
@graph.rdfs:label: Password Authentication

@graph.d3f:definition: Password rotation is a security policy that mandates the periodic change of user account passwords to mitigate the risk of unauthorized access due to compromised credentials.
@graph.rdfs:label: Password Rotation

@graph.d3f:definition:
Hardening components of a Platform with the intention of making them more difficult to exploit.

Platforms includes components such as:
* BIOS UEFI Subsystems
* Hardware security devices such as Trusted Platform Modules
* Boot process logic or code
* Kernel software components
@graph.rdfs:label: Platform Hardening

@graph.d3f:definition: Comparing the cryptographic hash or derivative of a pointer's value to an expected value.
@graph.rdfs:label: Pointer Authentication

@graph.d3f:definition: Ensuring that a pointer variable has the required properties for use.
@graph.rdfs:label: Pointer Validation

@graph.d3f:definition: Preventing execution of any address in a memory region other than the code segment.
@graph.rdfs:label: Process Segment Execution Prevention

@graph.d3f:definition: Adding physical barriers to a platform to prevent undesired radio interference.
@graph.rdfs:label: RF Shielding

@graph.d3f:definition: Invalidating all pointers that reference a specific memory block, ensuring that the block cannot be accessed or modified after deallocation.
@graph.rdfs:label: Reference Nullification

@graph.d3f:definition: Randomizing the base (start) address of one or more segments of memory during the initialization of a process.
@graph.rdfs:label: Segment Address Offset Randomization

@graph.d3f:definition: Replacing old software on a computer system component.
@graph.rdfs:label: Software Update

@graph.d3f:definition: Hardening source code with the intention of making it more difficult to exploit and less error prone.
@graph.rdfs:label: Source Code Hardening

@graph.d3f:definition: Comparing a value stored in a stack frame with a known good value in order to prevent or detect a memory segment overwrite.
@graph.rdfs:label: Stack Frame Canary Validation

@graph.d3f:definition: Modifying system configuration to increase password strength.
@graph.rdfs:label: Strong Password Policy

@graph.d3f:definition: Restricting system configuration modifications to a specific user or group of users.
@graph.rdfs:label: System Configuration Permissions

@graph.d3f:definition: Assuring the integrity of a platform by demonstrating that the boot process starts from a trusted combination of hardware and software and continues until the operating system has fully booted and applications are running.  Sometimes called Static Root of Trust Measurement (STRM).
@graph.rdfs:label: TPM Boot Integrity

@graph.d3f:definition: Token-based authentication is an authentication protocol where users verify their identity in exchange for a unique access token. Users can then access the website, application, or resource for the life of the token without having to re-enter their credentials.
@graph.rdfs:label: Token-based Authentication

@graph.d3f:definition: Token binding is a security mechanism used to enhance the protection of tokens, such as cookies or OAuth tokens, by binding them to a specific connection.
@graph.rdfs:label: Token Binding

@graph.d3f:definition: Validating that server components of a messaging infrastructure are authorized to send a particular message.
@graph.rdfs:label: Transfer Agent Authentication

@graph.d3f:definition: A trusted library is a collection of pre-verified and secure code modules or components that are used within software applications to perform specific functions. These libraries are considered reliable and have been vetted for security vulnerabilities, ensuring they do not introduce risks into the application.
@graph.rdfs:label: Trusted Library

@graph.d3f:definition: Setting variables to a known value before use.
@graph.rdfs:label: Variable Initialization

@graph.d3f:definition: Ensuring that a variable has the correct type.
@graph.rdfs:label: Variable Type Validation

@graph.d3f:definition: The harden tactic is used to increase the opportunity cost of computer network exploitation. Hardening differs from Detection in that it generally is conducted before a system is online and operational.
@graph.rdfs:label: Harden
